 You will never be looked at as more than a replaceable cog in a giant machine.  It also works to your detriment to have a high salary.  When it comes time to cut the fat around a department, they'd rather have someone with 0 experience who can just barely do the job at a 40% discount.

job_title: Customer Service Representatitve in Newark, DE
pros:
*Pay
*Benefits
*Employee Engagement - they really try their best in each department to do fun things to keep up moral and break monotony
*Career opportunities if you put in the work i.e. do well at your job, network, participate in development programs and other events
*Stability - Bank of America laid off NO ONE during the pandemic! (fired is one thing lol - laid off is another - no one was laid off)
*Development programs
cons:
**Really the same for any large company so its actually NOT a poke at BOA (and not just because I work here its true) when you are a large company to make 1 SMALL change to make a process better theres a lot of red tape you have to get through to get it done because of diff departments and regulations etc. - that kind of stuff annoys me but it is what it is. There are processes in place to present new ideas and ways to do things so im not saying the company isn't FOR change - im just saying certain things happens slower then I would like or rather slower than it should
**The other con is especially with what happened in 2020 i.e. the pandemic I think the corporate office model is outdated, working in a cubicle, the schedules available, the environment - I think an overhaul is in need (but that technically applies to any large corporation using this office model). The time for different office set ups, outside accessibility to sitting areas during breaks, and work from home schedules becoming more normal - is now.

review_title: Good for Entry Level, Good for Retirement, Bad for everything else
pros:
Big company, standard wall street benefits including 15 days Vacation and average medical plans. 401k 5% match and the usual standards
- Great for a fresh college grad with no credentials, down on their luck and rejected from top tier banks like JP, MS, or GS. Fill up that empty resume with one or two years of work before applying to one of the many better banks.
- Great for middle- aged employees with families to care for that aren't looking for career growth, and just want to clock their 9-5ers and collect basic paychecks. Can just coast towards retirement without doing much work and having much stress
cons:
- In Equities technology, you get some really garbage projects, doing data warehousing or OATS compliance work which contributes nothing to career growth and isn't quite marketable to future employers. 
- 1% to 5% yearly bonuses in a good year. 0% bonuses otherwise
- No base adjustments in salary unless you transfer jobs
- Discrimination from the business side. The business side, strats traders, etc, take all the bonuses and laugh in the face of their Technology teams. Technology folks get no respect and are treated like 4th class citizens in the bank, including being moved out of the main corporate building into a rental office space. Technology is a cost center and receives the lowest budget and worst reputation.
- Turnover among young people (aged ,<25) is very high, up to 80% last year. Six months after I left, a few applications nearly folded (or merged) because all their young employees also left.
